reviews.text: it’s almost impossible to recommend this over the other two games
inexplicably warning that any character created can’t be deleted later
the game doesn’t give you enough context on your character and the game doesn’t even allow for a way to look back on story events later if you want a refresher
Quick Match is nice for completinging missions with a group you didn’t have to organize yourself
you can’t know what mission you are going to get
missions themselves are horrendously bland. You find yourself going corridor to corridor along linear pathways until you hit a battle
the game doesn’t look good
jumping is so floaty that it has a glide to it. As for the air dash, it is so hopelessly short that more often than not you’ll find yourself falling into exactly what you hoped to jump over
four separate weapons to use interchangeably is a neat idea
combat becomes routine, and that is something you can certainly blame on mission layout
Bablyon’s Fall feels like it was made to check a box, because it is just so empty and slapped together
character design is awful and leaves everyone devoid of expression
important story context given by NPCs you have no reason to seek out

the part of the equipment menu that gives you a rundown of your actual stats, but it is relegated to the bottom of the menu in extremely small font. There is no pop-up tutorial explaining any of this so you have to figure it out on your own
you don’t learn how to craft gear until what feels like too far into the game. ... It isn’t until after the final boss that you unlock the function to upgrade gear
better gear has to be sacrificed for worse but higher power level pieces
assuming it survives this rocky launch
the game’s oil painting aesthetic makes textures look bad
